div.head: Objectives
div.p: The goal of this experiment is to measure angular dependent Fe 1s2p Resonant Inelastic X-ray Scattering (RIXS) on single crystal Fe 3 O 4 below and above the Curie temperature (T C ~858K). We aim to address the following points through our measurement:

1. Assign spectral features to specific Fe sites taking advantage of the spectral details revealed in the RIXS-LD planes on the basis of ligand field multiplet calculations. 2. Map the symmetry of the unoccupied orbitals from the measurement of the 360 o angular behaviour of the dichroic features. The orbital selectivity of the angular dependence combined with the site selectivity of Fe 1s2p RIXS enables us to probe site selectively the symmetry of the unoccupied orbitals. 3. Disentangle the interplay between structural and magnetic dichroism by following the temperature dependence of the dichroic signal below and above the T C of Fe 3 O 4 . 4. Validate the theoretical angular dependence of the RIXS cross-section in the presence and absence of exchange field.

div.head: Experiment details 2.1 Samples
div.p: Magnetite is a naturally occurring metastable form of iron oxide that has a chemical formula of Fe 3 O 4 . It crystallizes in a cubic (isometric) crystal system, with the oxide anions arranged in a cubic close-packed lattice. The cations (Fe 2+ and Fe 3+ ) are arranged in an inverse spinel structure such that half of the Fe 3+ cations occupy the octahedral (O h ) sites and the other half occupies the tetrahedral (T d ) sites in the lattice (shown in Figure 1). On the other hand, all the Fe 2+ cations occupy the O h sites. The crystal lattice constant is of 8.397Å at standard room conditions. Fe 3 O 4 is a ferrimagnetic material where the magnetic moments of Fe cations in T d and O h sites are coupled antiferromagnetically. The following samples were measured during the beamtime:

div.head: Beamline configuration
div.p: -The incident energy was selected using a pair of Si(311) crystals for high energy resolution. The spot size on the smaple position was 100*600 um 2 .
-Linear horizontal polarized X-rays were used during the experiment.
-A set of four spherically bent Ge(440) analyzer crystals with masks were used for high resolution (~0.5 eV as deduced from the FWHM of the elastic peaks).
-The spectrometer was set in a back scattering configuration with an angle of 15 degrees from the incident beam in order to maximize the signal seen by the crystals

div.head: Room temperature setup
div.p: The room temperature setup consists of: -Huber 360 degrees rotational stage.
-Set of permenant magnets.

-Adaptive plate with two possible configurations for mounting the magnets; longitudinal configuration where the magnetic field is parallel to the incident wave vector (k) and transverse configuration where the magnetic field is perpendicular to k (refer to Figure 2).

div.head: High temperature setup
div.p: The high temperature setup was designed to operate either under vacuum (~10 -6 mbar) or under static over-pressure of inert gas (pressure<1.3 bar inside the furnace) to presvent oxidation of Fe 3 O 4 at high temperatures. The high temperature setup consists of:  Huber 360 degrees rotational stage.  Furnace that can heat up to 1000 o C under vacuum (micro-tomo furnace borrowed from the sample environment).  Be dome cover (500 um thick) for the furnace to withstand the temperature and pressure requirements while having satisfactory transmission in the energy range from 6.4 to 7.2 KeV (the dome was borrowed from ID28).  Slip ring to input the cooling water and the gases to the furnace without having to allow for rotating the furnace without rotating the cooling and gas tubing (DSTI LT-2141).  Cold N 2 gun for cooling the Be dome and removing any formed ozone from the surface of the Be dome.  Vacuum turbo-pump (reaches ~10 -7 mbar).  High purity He gas (BIP He, O 2 < 10ppm) for experiments done under static over-pressure of inert gas.  Pressure relief valve and a burst disk to regulate the pressure of the inert gas during heating.  A relay controlled system that switches the heating off if the temprature of the Be window exceeds 200 o C.

The setup design (see Figure 3) allows us to:  Rotate the sample 300 o about the surface normal at high temperatures (upto 1000 o C) under vacuum (~1x10 -6 mbar at 1000 o C). The high temperature setup proofed to work well during the first measurments (sample 1 and 2 were succesfully measured without oxidation). However, at the end of the experiment, the slip ring malfunctioned and the water cooling circuit leaked water into the He gas circuit. This lead to the oxidation of sample 6 at high temperature. In-order to avoid such leakages in future experiments, the slip ring will only be used for the water cooling circuit and the gases will be delivered directly to the furnace without using the slip ring.

div.head: (110) Fe 3 O 4 single crystal in the transverse configuration
div.p: We present here the results of the ( 110 quadrupole angular behaviour for all features except that at incident energy = 7.1143 KeV and emission energy of 6.40537 KeV (shown in black in Figure 10b). It can be seen that the features at incidence energy 7.11331 and 7.1151 KeV are not overlapping as in Figure 7b. Comparing with this result with CFM calculations of the three Fe sites in Fe 3 O 4 (Figure 11), we observe this shift for the Fe 2+ O h sites with spinorbit coupling of the 3d valence electrons=100%. Thus we conclude that the shift is a sensitive probe of the spin-orbit coupling and the exchange field interaction.

div.head: High temperature measurement
div.p: In an attempt to gain a better understanding of the linear dichroism signal, we study RIXS-LD as a function of temperature. The long range order of the magnetic moments of Fe in Fe 3 O 4 is destroyed at temperatures higher than the Curie temperature (T C ~858K). Making use of the fact that the crystal field dichroism should not exhibit any temperature dependence, in contrast with the magnetic part which scales with <M 2 >, helps us disentangle both effects and determine their relative strength.

div.head: (110) Fe 3 O 4 powder
div.p: Figure 12 shows the HERFD XANES scans as a function of temperature during heating scans. The sample was heated up to 988 o C in vacuum (~10 -6 mbar). Some spectral changes could be seen in the pre-edge region. Comparing the spectral shape of the Fe 3 O 4 at 988 o C to Fe 2 O 3 , we conclude that the sample did not oxidise (Figure 13). This could also be confirmed from the phase diagram shown in Figure 14. This measurement confirmed that the setup works however no angular dependences could be measured for this sample because it is a powder. RT 988 o C a) b) a) b)

div.head: (110) Fe 3 O 4 natural crystal
div.p: Figure 15 shows the HERFD XANES scans as a function of temperature during heating scans of sample 2. The sample was heated up to 898 o C in vacuum (~10 -6 mbar). The same spectral changes could be seen in the pre-edge region. However, the quality of the natural commercial crystal is not good (possibly the crystal has many defects and high mosaicity) as no angular dependence could be observed at room temperature of high temperature (Figure 16) .

div.head: (110) Fe 3 O 4 single crystal
div.p: Figure 17 shows the pre-edge region of HERFD XANES of (110) Fe 3 O 4 single crystal (sample 6). As can be seen, the sample is oxidized at 900 o C and the pre-edge looks like that of Fe 2 O 3 (shown in brown). This is because the slip ring leaked water vapour into the furnace. 4. div.head: Future work
div.p: The high temperature experiment has been attempted in HC-2266 and proofed initially to work, however due to a malfunction of an equipment (slip ring provided by the ESRF), Fe 3 O 4 oxidized to α-Fe 2 O 3 at high temperatures and therefore we would like to reinvestigate this part.
